displayed_text: Patient: Right. So, I mean, as I said, I prefer to, to, to keep that to the last option, chemotherapy. Just because of, uh, how draining it is. Doctor: Right. Patient: B_, and my presumption is, if I stay with what I’m doing, that the PSA will continue to rise. As long as it continues to rise, it seems, um, with all the drugs I’ve had, it keeps going up. Doctor: Correct. So, when we did all the research with Enzalutamide, uh, patients on those studies stayed on treatment until either one of two things happened. Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: They felt worse and the, because of the cancer or the scan showed new disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, that’s where we’re sort of in this legal stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, it’s not that I think that (Zytiga) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And, I can’t.

Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh so right now you’re eligible for that. Maybe put that on the back burner. The one thing that would make you ineligible is going on chemotherapy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We sort of made that be like uh a line in the sand so to speak, so- Patient: What about the PSMA, uh? Doctor: So that was going to be the next thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Uh, we, there’s going to be a trial that’s a multi-centered trial that coming on-line, but it’s going to be a while. Uh, right now I think the trial is still ongoing at Cornell.

Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

Patient: I feel comfortable now. I mean. Doctor: Okay. All right. Then I think you should- Patient: As long as we can work around- Doctor: Yeah. We’ll try and work around most of those dates. If, only it becomes a problem, we may have to delay it, doing your second eye or whatever. Family Member: Because it’s all, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s almost every three weeks. Patient: Yeah. I don’t know if, yeah, if we screw up. Family Member: These are all the dates on all the different things he has to work through for cataract surgery. Doctor: Yeah. These are just the follow-ups. One week, one day, two weeks, and four weeks. Okay. That’s not a big deal. All uh. And those days are changeable. I mean, we can do Monday versus another. Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too.

Patient: But that’s a pretty significant consideration. Doctor: Yes oh absolutely and you know you have the exact indication for requiring Xtandi now. My concern is is it worth it because the Xtandi really did take us too far in terms of giving you control from the cancer. So honestly for the Lynparza I would really push for getting the Lynparza… Patient: The Lynparza is the uh inhibitor? Doctor: Is the pills. The PARP inhibitor. Yes. For the BRCA mutation. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct. Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If we got audited, it would be well, you’re not even taking care of him so what are you writing all this stuff for… Patient: Right. Doctor: …but you’re gonna be under our care for the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll just assume that at this point otherwise you’re driving here, you’re driving there, it makes no sense. Patient: Right. Doctor: and things may change when you’re on the study and we have to sort of make these changes ourselves so it’s better if we just do it. Family Member: Yeah, I agree Healthcare Professional: He can’t see the pain clinic here? Doctor: He can see the pain clinic here but are you almost out of your Percocet? Patient: Yeah, I want to say I have maybe, yeah.

Patient: Very good. Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: So what would the, uh, CAT scan show today? Just soft tissue? Patient: She doesn’t know yet. Family Member: maybe it’ll show Doctor: Well, I think maybe his disease was mainly in the lymph nodes. So that is what we will be following and the spine is visible on the CAT scan, too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So we might as well get an impression of what the bones, what’s going on in the lower back, and all of that, as well as mainly the lymph nodes is what I want to keep an eye on. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But I think maybe the Xofigo is still doing its stuff. Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Your husband did a good job. Doctor: As long as everything is in remission. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: On and off, I guess I’ll compliment him, then. (Laughter)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Twice, uh, I think they are seventy milligrams twice a day. Doctor: Okay – again, they’re a hundred and fifty or three hundreds? Patient: Oh, okay. Then they must be a hundred and fifties. Doctor: And so you take it once a day or twice a day? Patient: Twice a day. Patient: I try to get a thousand milligrams in. Doctor: Do you take that twice? Patient: Yeah. It depends. Sometimes I’m on gel pills and sometimes I’m on pills, pills. Doctor: So, those are the three medicines you take? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So the Eliquis, the Wellbutrin, and your calcium with vitamin D in it? Patient: Right. Doctor: Nothin’ new? Nothing new for bowels? Anything for pain?

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, that’s why they can see scarring on CAT scans, but that’s just again, inflammation. Um. And they love to use . And then, the only change that we see is in your right adrenal gland. Patient: MM, hmm. Doctor: And they’re saying there’s a nodular appearance, and there’s inflammation around it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, they don’t know what it is. I went up there. That’s why I wasn’t in right when you got here ‘cuz I wanted to go over it with the radiologist. Like, can you tell me what you think it is, and they don’t know. They’re hedging. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: You know what it’s like. Like, book wise, I had to. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: She’s in better shape than I am. Doctor: Okay. No. I, and, uh, especially if your vision’s an issue. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So I think we’ll try and work around those dates, then. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay. As much as we can. Patient: Can I sign now, and-? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When do I have to sign? Doctor: Oh. You have to sign when you are feeling- when you feel comfortable. It’s just that-

Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard. Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

Family Member: Okay. We’re done. Doctor: I think so. I never did this before. This is my first time. So. Family Member: Okay. Patient: This was on film? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Oh. Doctor: We’re supposed to be talking about clinical trials which I think we did; although, we didn’t enroll you in one. Patient: No, you answered my questions. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: You answered my questions. Doctor: But, I think, uh, the study is looking at how we talk about clinical trials, and, I think there is a racial component looking at --- Patient: Yeah, there is –

Healthcare Professional: You had one, oh yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, that’s what my daughter has taken. It’s pretty old. It still runs great. Family Member: She can’t walk out the front door and be on the same level as you know. She’d got to go down a little bit before she can come back. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: every kid needs thinking they’re going to change. Doctor: Yeah, no I wouldn’t give them new cars anyway. Patient: That’s normal to buy a new car, yeah. Doctor: Who wants to pay that insurance, too? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so now we will probably move you guys to Wednesday, Tuesday or Wednesday. Which day would you prefer? Family Member: You pick. Patient: Wednesday’s fine.

Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Then, I will be able to space it further and further apart. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the first two or three months are going to be somewhat critical. Patient: The same what we did with the Casodex? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Patient: No problem. Doctor: But, I cannot be putting you on medications and then leaving you with whatever you’re dealing with. Okay. Just like that.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Be to go to a intravenous chemotherapy. Okay. I don’t think I’m going to recommend that for you right now because your symptoms seem to be relatively mild. I’m not fully convinced to whether the pain that you had yesterday was attracted to cancer or could’ve been through something . I’ll try this route Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The chemotherapy has a name. It’s called Docetaxel and it has a second name and that is Taxotere. And this is given through the vein, intravenous, also called I.V. Intravenous I.V. It’s given once every few weeks. And I’m writing this down as an option just so you know what we talked about. But at this point in time, um I think that your cancer is progressing relatively slowly, if at all. Probably at slowly. And I don’t see any immediate need right now to recommend the chemotherapy. But it is an option, we’ll save that for later. I wanna focus our conversation now on the fresh option, which is the Xtandi. So in general in patients who have previously received Abiraterone, that could’ve been you, you would’ve been taking it but you were unable to get access to it for the last two months. Patient: Right. Doctor: If if that is no longer affected then the second drug, Xtandi, uh typically works for about six, sometimes nine months. So it, it doesn’t work for years and years but it does give us a little bit more time before we have to recommend the chemotherapy.
